user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#if defined(HAVE_CPUSET_GETAFFINITY)
  /* FreeBSD style */
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    cpuset_t cur_mask;
    /* The should get "anonymous" mask/set. The anonymous mask is always
       a subset of the assigned set (which is a subset of the root set). */
    if (0 == cpuset_getaffinity (CPU_LEVEL_WHICH, CPU_WHICH_PID, (id_t) -1,
                                 sizeof (cur_mask), &cur_mask))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_CPU_COUNT
      ret = CPU_COUNT (&cur_mask);
#else  /* ! HAVE_CPU_COUNT */
      unsigned int i;
      ret = 0;
      for (i = 0; i < CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE; ++i)
      {
        if (CPU_ISSET (i, &cur_mask))
          ++ret;
      }
      if (0 == ret)
        ret = -1;
#endif /* ! HAVE_CPU_COUNT */
    }
  }
#ifdef HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* Use 256 times larger size than size for default maximum CPU number.
       Hopefully it would be enough even for exotic situations. */
    static const unsigned int mask_size_cpus = 256 * CPU_SETSIZE;
    const size_t mask_size_bytes = CPU_ALLOC_SIZE (mask_size_cpus);
    cpuset_t *p_mask;

    p_mask = CPU_ALLOC (mask_size_cpus);
    if (NULL != p_mask)
    {
      if (0 == cpuset_getaffinity (CPU_LEVEL_WHICH, CPU_WHICH_PID, (id_t) -1,
                                   mask_size_bytes, p_mask))
      {
#ifndef MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS
        ret = CPU_COUNT_S (mask_size_bytes, p_mask);
#else  /* MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS */
        ret = CPU_COUNT_S (mask_size_cpus, p_mask);
#endif /* MHD_FUNC_CPU_COUNT_S_GETS_CPUS */
      }
      CPU_FREE (p_mask);
    }
  }
#endif /* HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S */
#endif /* HAVE_CPUSET_GETAFFINITY */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_:
#define CPU_SETSIZE_SAFE CPU_SETSIZE
...
#define HAVE_CPU_COUNT 1
...
#define HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S 1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined the provided function and there are no calls to any of the Standard Library string.h functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (no use of memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.). Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that fall under the scope of Rule 21.17 and need investigation for accesses beyond the bounds of objects via those string.h functions.

Notes on other constructs (not in scope for Rule 21.17):
- The calls to cpuset_getaffinity(...) and the use of CPU_ALLOC/CPU_ALLOC_SIZE/CPU_FREE/CPU_COUNT_S manipulate buffers and sizes, but these are not functions from <string.h>. Although such calls should be checked for correct size/pointer use under other safety/robustness rules, they are not relevant to MISRA Rule 21.17 as given and thus are not reported here.
- Conditional compilation (HAVE_CPU_COUNT, HAVE_CPU_COUNT_S) only affects which CPU-counting path is used; none of the compiled paths invoke string.h functions.

Because Rule 21.17 strictly concerns the listed <string.h> functions, and none are present in the target code, there are no suspicious fragments to report for this rule.
